thread.title: O’Neal tabbed for San Antonio Sports Hall of Fame

author: Tom Orsborn
title: O’Neal tabbed for San Antonio Sports Hall of Fame
text:

On the far right is current head coach Herb More who then was given the task of defending O’Neal during practices.
Photo: Kin Man Hui /San Photo of the 1989 Cole High School basketball squad where NBA star... Image 3 of 15 The trophy from the 3A state championship for Cole High School in basketball in 1989. Retired basketball star Shaquille O’Neal was honored during his high school jersey retirement ceremony at Cole High School on Friday, mar. 7, 2014. O’Neal graduated from Cole in 1989 and took the basketball team to a 3A State championship. The school honored O’Neal by retiring his jersey with an accompaniment of guests including his former coaches and teammates from Cole High.

Photo: Kin Man Hui /San Retired NBA star Shaquille O’Neal playfully asks for a spanking... The school honored O’Neal by retiring his jersey during a gathering of special guests, including his former coaches and teammates from Cole.
Photo: Kin Man Hui /San Shaquille O’Neal addresses the audience during his jersey... Image 15 of 15 O’Neal tabbed for San Antonio Sports Hall of Fame 1 / 15 Back to Gallery Shaquille O’Neal , who became one of the NBA ’s all-time dominant centers after leading Cole to the 1989 Class 3A basketball championship, headlines the San Antonio Sports Hall of Fame’s Class of 2016.
The other inductees include Darold Williamson , George Block and the ’89 Cole team spearheaded by a monumental season from O’Neal in which he averaged 32 points, 22 rebounds and 8 blocks.
O’Neal led the Cougars to a 68-1 record from 1987 through 1989. In his final year, he powered Cole to a 36-0 mark en route to the state title.
O’Neal played three years at LSU before he was picked first in the 1992 NBA draft by the Orlando Magic . He scored more than 28,000 points and won four NBA titles during a 19-year career, highlighted by his stint with the Los Angeles Lakers .
Block is best known for his work as director of aquatics at Northside Independent School District, where he worked for three decades. His career achievements at the school district included coaching six Olympians and 50 UIL medalists.
The district’s aquatic center is named after Block.
Williamson, a Holmes graduate, is an Olympic gold medalist and one of the most decorated athletes in the history of Baylor track and field. He won an NCAA title in the 400 meters for the Bears at the 2005 NCAA Outdoor Championships nearly one year after anchoring the United States to a gold medal in the 400-meter relay at the 2004 Summer Olympic Games in Athens, Greece.
The induction ceremony is set for Feb. 27 at the Convention Center.
For more go to ExpressNews.com
